awd_titl_txt: Establishing the synthesis/structure relationship of molybdenum/lead chalcogenide quantum dot mesocrystals
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical summary

With this project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, Professor Tobias Hanrath at Cornell University will explore the synthesis-structure relationships of a novel class of materials that combines nanoparticles with two-dimensional (2D) materials. By analogy to the rock-paper-scissors game, the investigators will use colloidal nanoparticles (i.e., rocks) to template the formation of molybdenum sulfide sheets (i.e., paper) on specific sections of the nanoparticle. Instead of scissors, the proposed synthesis approach leverages the well-defined nanoparticle shape (e.g., truncated cubes) to define the geometry of the particle-sheet composite. This project will have significant broader impact beyond the creation of new knowledge of scientific and societal importance, potentially leading to the development of new nanostructured composite materials with unique optical, electronic, and catalytic properties. Graduate students will receive extensive training and experience at the confluence of material fabrication and characterization approaches to investigate, understand and predict the formation of composite nanostructures. Outreach and education are closely integrated with the scientific work. The investigators will develop a ‘back-to-the-future’ workshop to engage participants by developing their vision for the future of their specific research field, the broader technological implications, and their personal roles and opportunities in bringing this future to fruition. 

Technical Summary 

The overarching objective of the proposed project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, is to establish the foundational synthesis/structure relationship of molybdenum/lead chalcogenide quantum dot mesocrystals. Mesocrystals are defined as assemblies of smaller constituent crystals arranged with high degree of translational and orientational ordering in their superlattice sites. Access to colloidal quantum dot (QD) building blocks with precisely defined size, shape, and composition as well as concurrent progress in understanding of and control over directed assembly and attachment have enabled remarkable advances in QD mesocrystals. Currently available QD mesocrystals are limited to single composition structures, yet the scientific and technological evolution of isolated QDs has taught us that moving from single-components to multi-composition heterostructures (e.g., core-shell or Janus-like) introduces advanced and programmable functionalities. The PI has identified the synthesis and analysis of heterostructured QD mesocrystals as a scientifically interesting and technologically important research challenge. The PI embraces the challenge of establishing processing/structure relationships as an opportunity to closely integrate synthesis, assembly, and materials characterization. The proposal presents a hypothesis-driven approach with three complementary objectives focused on formation of facet-specific PbX-(MoS2)m misfit layer heterostructures, and directed assembly of isolated PbX-(MoS2)m into a new class of superstructures. The proposed research presents an exciting opportunity to significantly improve upon the knowledge of QD mesocrystals with properties by design. The goals of the proposed research are ambitious, and the generated knowledge will significantly advance basic understanding, design, predictability and control over heterostructured QD mesocrystals with compelling far-reaching prospects for future advances in electrocatalysis and optoelectronics

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project set out to explore an ambitious frontier in nanomaterials science: the creation of complex quantum dot (QD) superstructures with programmable properties, achieved through site-specific doping. The work focused on a special class of materials called mesocrystals, which are highly ordered assemblies of nanoscale building blocks that combine the advantages of both single crystals and nanomaterials.

At the heart of the project was the hypothesis that these mesocrystals, made from lead chalcogenide quantum dots, could serve as a platform to introduce dopant atoms, such as molybdenum, at specific atomic sites within the crystal lattice. If successful, this would open the door to a new generation of nanomaterials with highly tailored electronic, catalytic, and optical properties—materials “by design” with the potential to transform applications from energy storage and conversion to quantum information systems.

To test this idea, the research team synthesized quantum dot mesocrystals with precise size, shape, and crystal orientation. Building on previous work in ion-exchange chemistry, the team attempted to selectively replace lead atoms with molybdenum dopants at specific crystal facets. These experiments were guided by computational models and leveraged recent advances in self-assembly techniques.

Unfortunately, the experimental findings did not support the initial hypothesis. Detailed compositional analyses using advanced tools like X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) showed that the doping process did not proceed in a site-specific manner. Instead, the quantum dot surfaces exhibited significant structural disorder, which interfered with the controlled incorporation of dopant atoms. These results highlight an important insight: while computational models may suggest idealized outcomes, real-world materials often present unexpected complexities—especially at the nanoscale.

Despite not achieving site-specific doping, the project delivered valuable scientific outcomes. The experiments expanded understanding of the relationship between quantum dot surface chemistry, structural ordering, and doping behavior. The results revealed new challenges and opportunities for working with mesocrystals, including how subtle variations in morphology can impact chemical reactivity. These insights will inform future research in nanomaterials synthesis and the design of functional heterostructures.

In parallel with the technical research, the project also produced a successful educational initiative: the Back to the Future foresight workshop. This workshop was designed to help engineering students and early-career researchers think creatively about the long-term societal and technological impacts of their work. Drawing inspiration from the iconic film, the workshop guided participants through a series of interactive exercises—including writing letters to their future selves and mapping imagined scientific timelines—to reflect on how today’s discoveries might shape tomorrow’s world.

The workshop was implemented in multiple settings, including classroom discussions, faculty retreats, and research symposia. It fostered a deeper sense of engineering identity and helped participants connect their technical efforts to broader societal goals. The format proved to be highly adaptable and engaging, with strong potential for continued use in STEM education and professional development.
